featured.text: Only a third of people are disturbed by the song in their heads.
A culture’s folk tales, fables, songs, and proverbs are an important part of its literature.
Often those songs have a simple, upbeat melody and catchy, repetitive lyrics, such as popular commercial jingles and slightly annoying radio hits.
The rain plays a little sleep-song on our roof at night－ And I love the rain.

other.text: The singers usually sing popular folk songs.

Many times nowadays, it is the children who teach the songs to their parents, putting back the pieces of a blurred memory.”
“It used to be that the only ones who could sing these songs were tribal elders aged between 50 and 60.
In Song of Solomon, for example, Morrison tells the story of an African American man and his search for identity in his culture.
Recent or repeated exposure to a song or even a small part of a song can also trigger earworms, as can word associations, such as a phrase similar to the lyrics of a song.

Those who have positive feelings about their stuck songs prefer to just “let them be,” while those with negative feelings turn to more behavioral responses, which include coping strategies such as singing, talking, or even praying. 49.
In addition, the songs are seemingly trying to work some magic—as if, by singing, the mother is saying, “Sadness has already touched this house; no need to come by again.” 53.
Researchers are not sure why some songs are more likely to get stuck in our heads than others, but everyone has their own tunes.
They use a range of terms to describe it—stuck-song syndrome, sticky music, cognitive itch, or most commonly “earworm.”

definition.zh_def: 歌曲；由音樂和歌詞組成的藝術作品。
definition.en_def: A musical composition typically consisting of lyrics and melody.
definition.example: She sang her favorite song at the concert.
